--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
>> ...you don't want to be coding it by hand.
> 
> I'm not...

Good. :)

> >The power of SVG comes from leveraging data stored in
> >XML format.
> 
> Sure, but you could use it to visualize anything, whether it was in 
> XML or not.

This is true.  If it's better and more efficient than using the 
graphical API for whatever language you're working in, great.

> Speaking of which, I finally got my network visualization algorithm 
tuned 
> properly, with the forces of attraction vs. repulsion balanced so 
as to 
> create the appropriate shape.  I've uploaded a sample to the files 
section 
> of the group so you guys can see it.  This is the 'simplified' one, 
with 
> only 147 nodes and their relationships.  The full data set has 63k 
> nodes...there's no way I'd ever be able to view that one!!!

Hmm...looks pretty cool.  Is every node connected to every other one, 
just with different strengths?  That would make over 20K connections, 
which is going to take a long time to render.  

And I don't think there would any really feasible way to represent a 
single graph of 63K nodes.  The conceptual linking does remind me 
somewhat of The Brain (Enterprise Knowledge Platform), a conceptual 
hyperlinking engine (http://www.thebrain.com/).  It's used by 
KurzweilAI.com as a subject index...here's the page on AI:

http://www.kurzweilai.net/brain/frame.html?startThought=Artificial%
20Intelligence%20(AI)

> Do you have a good SVG online reference that you use?  

The W3Schools tutorial is pretty good:

http://www.w3schools.com/svg/default.asp

It does a good job of relating the attributes of each of the 
graphical tags.  Honestly, when I was learning the basics of SVG, I 
bought the O'Reilly book and mostly tinkered with examples from the 
text.  You can do all sorts of fancy stuff with SVG, including 
animation, but I've stuck to just rendering basic shapes, paths, and 
text.

Derek
